text: Gosh, that sounds like a major rethink!
I was just looking back over our correspondence and I don't think I ever properly answered your question about prep, production and post! I got stuck explaining the position I am in at the moment.
Shall we go back to the original question and try again?
Prep - once you have secured funding for the film you go into prep.
There's an old addage that you make your film 3 times, there's the one you write, the one you shoot and the one you edit.
I'd say prep is when you start writing the one you shoot.

If you have a look at Sidney Lumet's book, he really talks about filmmaking in the most practical terms. He made a lot of movies so he knows the pattern of production inside out and has enough odd stories to make his explanations amusing.

When you go into prep you need to understand that you have a finite amount of time to gather all the resources you're going to need to make your film. You need to sort out all your locations and have access to get familiar with them before you take your crew there. You can delegate a lot of the locations work to your designer and the location team, but you need to get familiar with them too and so does your DP.

You will work initially very closely with your producer, designer, locations team and casting director. You will also have to work closely with the line producer. You won't be able to have everything you want, so you'll have to know what you're willing to fight for and what you're willing to sacrifice.

This is also the period where you build your relationships. This is very important. You don't need to be an asshole, but you need to have authority. Personally, I try and get to know the people around me and I make a huge effort to learn everyone's name. It's a little thing that everyone appreciates and will pay dividends. It's not that hard either, even when you have a lot of people. I'll come back to this.

Similarly, if there is anyone who is disruptive and making it difficult for you to do your very best work then this the time to replace them. It's really difficult (I find it really difficult), but you won't get a better chance to make the most of the film your making than right now, so anyone who is not a fully committed member of the team should go and work with a team they can commit to and you should find someone else.

Losing people is inevitable and the circumstances are always going to be difficult. Some people appear to have built careers around being brutal in these circumstances, but personally I think it's ok to be straight forward and respectful, this is one movie and who knows who's path you will cross on the next one.
